metadata.value: Portion of verses and a summary from a bound copy of 'History of the Adventures, Deeds and Courageous Actions of the Hero and Knight Thewerdanck'.
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: 1 of 28. Loose vellum pages that were once bound. These pages include the poem "The Perilous Adventures of the Famous Hero and Knight Thewerdanck" ("Les Avantures perilleuses du fameux Heros & Chevalier Tewrdannecks"). The original poem is attributed to Melchoir Pfintzing (Pfinzing), Provost of Saint Sebald’s in Nuremburg, and is written in German (referred to for this poem in some bibliographies as the Teutonic language). The poem includes a Dedicatory Epistle addressed to Charles V in 1517 from Nuremburg, as well as 118 wooden plate engravings. The version of the poem collected here is a manuscript copy of the 1517 poem in its original language written out by Jacques Leclabart over the years 1771-72. Leclabart published the poem in the 1784 book _Hist. des Avantures, faits et actions courageuses due heros et Chevalier Thewerdanck_, which also includes a printed summary and history of the poem by Leclabart, both of which are written in French. As reported by the book’s introductory matter, Jacques Leclabart was a member of l'Academie Royale d'Ecriture de Paris.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: 24 of 28. Loose vellum pages that were once bound. These pages include the poem "The Perilous Adventures of the Famous Hero and Knight Thewerdanck" ("Les Avantures perilleuses du fameux Heros & Chevalier Tewrdannecks"). The original poem is attributed to Melchoir Pfintzing (Pfinzing), Provost of Saint Sebald’s in Nuremburg, and is written in German (referred to for this poem in some bibliographies as the Teutonic language). The poem includes a Dedicatory Epistle addressed to Charles V in 1517 from Nuremburg, as well as 118 wooden plate engravings. The version of the poem collected here is a manuscript copy of the 1517 poem in its original language written out by Jacques Leclabart over the years 1771-72. Leclabart published the poem in the 1784 book _Hist. des Avantures, faits et actions courageuses due heros et Chevalier Thewerdanck_, which also includes a printed summary and history of the poem by Leclabart, both of which are written in French. As reported by the book’s introductory matter, Jacques Leclabart was a member of l'Academie Royale d'Ecriture de Paris.
metadata.label: Description
